```{r global_options, include=FALSE}
# This is a way to set options for all code chunks at once
# Note that you can also dynamically control options by setting them to a value
# DPI setting increased for Word output, cairo is anti aliasing
# copied this from https://stackoverflow.com/questions/33445110/rmarkdown-global-options-vs-opts-chunk we may want to change the figure options
knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo=FALSE, warning=FALSE, message=FALSE, cache = FALSE,
                      dev="png", fig.width = 10, fig.height = 7, dpi=200, dev.args=list(type="cairo"))
```

```{r}
#| warning: false 
library(tidyverse) #c("A vector", "of strings")
library(here) 
library(ggplot2) 
library(haven) 
library(gridExtra) 
library(ggdist) 
library(ggthemes) 
library(gifski) 
library(magick) 
library(gt) 
library(gtExtras)
  
source(here::here("R scripts/set_paths.R")) 
source(here::here(params$data)) 
source(here::here("R scripts/Functions/raincloudplot.R")) 
source(here::here("R scripts/Functions/summary_functions.R")) 
source(here::here("R scripts/Functions/gif.R"))
set_name <- as.name(params$name_dataset)
waves <- max(get(set_name)[["wave"]])
data <- get(set_name)
```

Summary table

```{r}
#| warning: false
  
make_summary_table(data) |> 
  filter(name %in% params$variables)|> 
  gt() |> 
  gt_theme_espn()
```

Summary tables by wave

```{r}
#| warning: false
for (wav in 1:waves) {
  wave <- make_summary_by_wave(data)
  wave <- wave[[wav]] |> 
    filter(name %in% params$variables) |> 
    gt() |> 
    gt_theme_espn()
  print(wave)
}
  
```

Plots:

```{r}
#| warning: false
for (variable in params$variables) {
  plot <- make_raincloudplot(data[variable], paste(variable, "score"), params$colour)
  table <- make_summary_table(data) |> 
    filter(name == variable) |> 
    gt() |> 
    gt_theme_espn()
  print(plot)
  print(table)
}
```

GIFs:

```{r}

for (variable in params$variables) {
  gif <- make_raincloudplot_wave(data, variable, paste(variable, "score by wave"), params$colour)
  gif <- create_gif(gif)
  gif #i just read the documentation and print() shows the tibble that represents the gif so if it doesnt work with the object i dont know whats RMarkdowns problem
```
